article:
'Visibility' is a mathematical abstraction of the real-life notion of
visibility.

Given a set of obstacles in the Euclidean space, two points in the space are
said to be 'visible to each other', if the line segment that joins them does not
intersect any obstacles. (In the Earth's atmosphere light follows a slightly
curved path that isn't perfectly predictable, complicating the calculation of
actual visibility.)

Computation of visibility is among the basic problems in computational geometry
and has applications in computer graphics, motion planning, and other areas.
